title: Messenger forgets declaration
vignette: A divorce document is sent through a courier who forgets to state it was signed correctly.

options.text: The divorce is valid regardless.
Invalid without the declaration; resend a new divorce document.

title: Husband changes his mind
vignette: After sending the divorce papers via courier, the spouse regrets it and wants to cancel before delivery.

options.text: He may cancel it if he reaches the messenger first.
Too late once sent; it takes effect when delivered.

title: Conditional divorce if he doesn't return
vignette: The husband writes a divorce document that becomes valid if he fails to come home within a year while traveling abroad.

options.text: Such a conditional divorce document is binding if the condition occurs.
Conditions undermine the seriousness; it should be void.

title: Lost divorce document before reaching the wife
vignette: A courier loses the divorce document on the way. By the time he notices, it cannot be found.

options.text: Write a new get; the original is presumed destroyed.
Assume the divorce document may surface and she is divorced.

title: Husband mentally incapacitated
vignette: The filing spouse suffers a breakdown after authorising the divorce but before it's delivered.

options.text: The divorce proceeds since consent was earlier.
Suspend it until he recovers mental competence.

title: Messenger told to destroy after delivery
vignette: The husband instructs the agent to tear up the document immediately after handing it to the wife.

options.text: Valid; once given it effects divorce regardless.
Invalid because destruction prevents verification.

title: Coerced divorce by community
vignette: Neighbours and community leaders legally pressure a reluctant spouse until they sign the divorce papers.

options.text: Coercion invalidates the divorce.
If rabbinic court approved, it remains valid.

title: Scribal error in names
vignette: The clerk misspells one partner's name on the divorce decree.

options.text: Minor errors void the get; rewrite correctly.
As long as intent is clear, it works.

title: Electronic divorce document
vignette: The husband wants the scribe to prepare and send the divorce document digitally with electronic signatures.

options.text: Accept digital format if legally secure.
Require traditional parchment and ink.

title: Delivering the divorce document on rest day
vignette: The courier arrives on a strict no-work public holiday with the divorce document in hand.

options.text: Wait until after rest day to avoid desecration.
Deliver it immediately; the marital status matters.

title: Remote divorce via agent
vignette: A soldier listed as missing sends divorce instructions through a comrade with scant details.

options.text: Permitted; agency suffices for divorce.
He must return and deliver it himself.

title: Wife refuses to accept get
vignette: When the messenger arrives, the wife refuses to take the document from his hand.

options.text: Place it near her and consider it delivered.
Without her consent it has no effect.

title: Non-observant witness
vignette: One of the witnesses is a respected neighbour but not recognised by the couple's religious court.

options.text: Invalid; both witnesses must be observant men.
Accept his signature for peace between neighbors.

title: Get delivered to wrong person
vignette: The courier hands the envelope to a roommate who later loses it before the wife sees it.

options.text: Not valid; it must reach her hands.
She is divorced once the agent reached her home.

title: Husband missing in war
vignette: A soldier presumed captured sends a divorce document through another soldier with limited details.

options.text: Allow the divorce to free the wife from agunah status.
Demand thorough verification first.
